commentBody: Just opened the puzzle, loved seeing FACTORIAL.

This solved really fast--too fast for a Saturday, IMO--until it absolutely didn't. I ran aground at SPITS GAME, which I finally got from the crosses. Still, I finished in less than two-thirds my average Saturday time. I did enjoy a lot of the wordplay and cluing, and overall it was a pleasant experience.
I couldn‚Äôt get Mariah Carey to fit in 30 across?

Got a little tied up in the NW, but some clues here that were right up my alley. I was National Merit Scholar having aced my PSAT, and I knew my FACTORIALS quite well. 1, 2, 6, 24, 120, 720...

And food! Not a big fan of TAKIs, but I love SHAKSHUKA, AGEDCHEESE, and MAYO.

As for BIER and ALES, I can take it or leave it

How sad to learn John Oliver‚Äôs view of PUNS! 
Sure, there are ‚Äúbad‚Äù ones, but has he never experienced one DONE TO A TEE? One with just the perfect amount of HOKUM? The ARTISANAL pun with the fine flavor of AGED CHEESE? 

LET‚ÄôS FACE IT: he should hang out with our Mike some time.
I had the urge to put in BIDEN for 38A.
Mostly super fun and breezy--got to the SW corner going top speed and felt the lurch of getting suddenly stuck.
REIKI crossing TAKI?  Kind of a microcosm of this arcana-laden puzzle, at least for me.

I didn't enjoy the cluing, and I thought the slang phrase odd. Some answers just didn't make sense to me. I don't know what a spitsgame is and don't care to know. Gluon? Taki? I hate when the right answers seem wrong.

Still too easy, in keeping with the rest of the the last week, unfortunately.

I admit that at the end I was hung up for a few minutes with lame instead of game being spit (and laps instead of gaps), but that was the only "challenging" bit of the whole thing.  I'm sure I've not gotten much better.  This has just been a simple week for the NYT crossword.  Oh well.  (It wasn't a bad entry.  Just not quite the Saturday climb I was expecting.  Quite quick.)

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)
Can someone explain 19 across for me?
I'm guessing Eddie dun did this puzz. So dun I.

I don‚Äôt think this was particularly easy, but I have never had a puzzle written so precisely for me. ANIMALFARM, ZOOMIES and FACTORIAL were absolute gimmes, as was SHAKSHUKA which is a staple in our house (yum!). Loads of fun. The only misdirect I had was SPOUT instead of SPIEL for ‚Äúpitcher‚Äôs output‚Äù.
Filling in SnIT for [Small drama], crossed with a dish I'm not familiar with, slowed me down. I like SnIT better.

"Did you shred the cheese yet?"
"I'll get to it soon. Cheddar grate than never!"

("That's gouda-nough for me!")

Loved the quote from ANIMAL FARM.  

But LETS FACE IT, if George Orwell had one the chance, I‚Äôm sure he‚Äôd change 1984 to 2025.

SPITS GAME is talking smoothly????

Yuck.

Yesterday I got my fourth fastest Friday and today I got my third fastest Saturday. I might have had a personal best today if I had known SHAKSHUKA (I‚Äôll be looking for recipes for that soon). I smiled at seeing NORWEGIAN ELKHOUNDS in the grid. My oldest sister had one about 50 years ago, a sweet pup she named Tigger. (Why name a dog after a cat? Because there are no dogs in ‚ÄúWinnie-the-Pooh.‚Äù) But I really could have done without GLOCK. There‚Äôs only one reason I know that name. https://www.vice.com/en/article/glock-pistol-omar-mateen-orlando-mass-shooting/

I‚Äôm not up to skill level of the early birds here. At first I had nothing. Just blank, and thought the puzzle impossible.  But then SHAKSHUKA and THAT‚ÄôS ON ME got me a toe hold in the east. Lots of misdirects or perhaps just misses. Like wanting Last Round instead of LOSER PAYS. Muck before MESS. And on the tip of my tongue for OSAGE and REIKI. 

Gratifying to fill the last square (SPITS GAME) and get the happy music.

SHAKSHUKA?  REIKI? TAKI?   ZOOMIES?

I started feeling like AGED CHEESE while I chipped away at this one, but actually, it was DONE TO A TEE, with mostly enlightening crosses, and if have never before encountered someone who SPITS GAME or HAD NO CHILL, well LET'S FACE IT, it's not you, THAT'S ON ME. (I have to admit,  I CARE).

Classy puzzle, Mr. Lieberman.  Now I think I'll go to bed.
I‚Äôll never understand what determines a ‚ÄúTricky Clue‚Äù yet they‚Äôre always the ones I already solved. Never very helpful. How about giving away the actual tricky ones?

So I was ZOOMIn right along starting in the NE and thinking I was going to seriously beat my Saturday PB, feeling all smart remembering my PSAT score. Answers were just coming lickety split. Having had cats for years, I filled in ZOOMIES with no crosses. Yeah, they loll around all day, but come evening, they have NO CHILL. I was even filling in answers I didn't know I knew. Haven't thought about FACTORIALs since the early 80s. SHAKSHUKA I filled in from just a couple of crosses, and I still haven't figured out how I know it, but having tried a lot of different foods in my life, it's not that surprising. Most everything I didn't know filled easily from crosses until I got to that SW section. I probably spent as much time in that area as the rest of the puzzle. Having LOSERbuYS instead of LOSERPAYS didn't help. Finally got SPITSGAME from running the alphabet. Anyway, for those who care, here's an interesting 3-minute segment about the origin of that expression. https://waywordradio.org/spitting-game/ (Click the Listen in Browser button if you don't want to be redirected to SoundCloud) And btw, in case you're wondering, SPITS is the verb and GAME is the object.

Could somebody please explain why "Bass output" solves to ALES? Is Bass a brand of beer?

The puzzle was probably fair for its intended, American audience, but I ended up revealing 20 or so answers. Names, abbreviations - they will always be my nemesis. Not caring about my streak means reveals don't spoil my fun though üôÇ

SHAKSHUKA was a gimme, even though clueing it as North African confused me - I have always though of it as an Arab Middle Eastern, and Turkish dish. The clue prompted me to look up the etymology - some sources see a North African one, so maybe the clue was OK(ish). 

SHAKSHUKA is my favorite breakfast at Turkish bars, and I often make it myself for lunch or dinner. It's amazing how such simple ingredients result in such a full taste. I love it, and I also love the smile it brings to my wife's face: Middle Eastern food is her favorite.

Btw, in Polish your Middle East is Bliski Wsch√≥d (Near East) - probably because we are much nearer to it than English speakers ü§£

Polish trivia time! May 1st, Labor Day, and May 3rd, the anniversary of Poland's first Constitution of 1791, are both national holidays. They and the weekend combine into what is known as D≈Çugi Weekend, the Long Weekend, a Polish institution. You wouldn't believe how empty Warsaw has become - many of the city folk have left on week-long vacation, and those who stayed in town are enjoying their time off work - the streets are empty but smoke rises day after day over popular barbecue spots.

The comment section is still buggy with that new weird thing that happened yesterday: only clicking the timestamp of the original post reveals all it's replies. Some of them are not visible otherwise. 

Could somebody please report it to the NYT via email? I never got an answer to any of the messages I sent there, so I won't bother this time, but maybe Americans will be treated more seriously.

Cool puzzle, liked kicking it off with Animal Farm. And in the 'today I learned' section is the phrase 'has no chill'. Ths is new to me and something I'm looking forward to using, most likely incorrectly.
My new fastest Saturday solve at just under 17m, faster than both Th and F for me this week.

Where is Eddie to say he didn't 'done did this puzz'?? I need to feel better about how much I struggled with this one. Needed the article and some look ups for proper nouns, even then needed auto check to finish, brutal
I finished Friday's puzzle but it shows that I didn't. So now my winning streak has ended!! This is must be corrected!!  Please!

2D seems a little weak. And why spell out the T in 15A?

But I really really hate the colloquial phrases as clues, like 17A. They just seem lazy to me, way too many options to be known or guessed with any confidence.

Given that US exam abbreviations can be just about anything, I had GUNS for "The lowest form of human behavior".

But maybe that's just me (and John Oliver).

The Americanisms were killer. ADLAI and Estes? Bass ALES? Another exam with the PSAT? Haw many SATs do you all have?
NOELS for winter airs makes no sense at all, and not just because I live in the Southern Hemisphere. 
ESAU crossing OSAGE was a major natick for me. 
Maybe I HAVE NO CHILL but I had no idea what ‚Äúkeyed up‚Äù meant. 
I like hard, but this was just specific.

Oh boy, that was a tough one! 

The north east gave away fairly early on as I knew SHAKSHUKA (delicious!!) and the clue for AUDIOTOUR was fairly generous. That gave me a foothold to slowly inch my way through the bottom quadrants and was pretty stoked to finally figure out LOSERPAYS and SALEPRICE. Finally gave up after making no progress in the north-west corner - I only knew FACTORIAL there,  eventually got INTER and could otherwise only think of hungTOATEE - so was never going to be able to parse the ADLAI/ISLES/ISR/NOELS grouping. Didn‚Äôt help that Animal Farm is one of those classics I somehow never read! 

Oh well, gave it a good go but still only on 1 Saturday gold star for the year

@Eric Hougland

I'm writing this here because my other reply to you is hidden by the time stamp bug.

Click the time stamps of my two posts below - you will see additonal replies, including one in which I described this weird bug.

It's not like we paying a subscription here that could finance an upgrade of the sorry excuse for software the NYT seems to be using for this comment board... Oh, wait.
Thanks to SHAKSHUKA and FACTORIAL this was a quick Saturday for me. Very funny to see the clue ‚ÄúBass output‚Äù having grown up not too far from Burton-on-Trent.

Whew - this one was even tougher than the usual Saturday for me. Eleven debut answers and six others that were only in one other puzzle. Don't recall seeing that before. And some of those were never going to occur to me. Anyway... a bit of cheating and then just a whole lot of pondering and working the crosses. THATS(all)ONME. And.. my usual puzzle finds today. First - a Sunday from March 11, 1973 by J.A. Felker with the title: "Answering Service" Never seen another one like this. Five 23 letter grid spanning theme answers, and it was all in the clues. Sort of a reverse of clues and answers in a way. Here they are: "Forget-me-not" WHATISTHEFLOWEROFALASKA "Snails, for one" WHATARELITTLEBOYSMADEOF "Two" HOWMANYPINTSAREINAQUART "Tipperary" WHEREISITALONGLONGWAYTO "Rome" WHEREARETHESPANISHSTEPS Pretty amazing. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=3/11/1973&g=67&d=A I'll put the other puzzle in a reply. ...

Andrzej, I see now what you‚Äôre talking about. 

I replied to your comment about barbecuing in Warsaw with a description of how I cook outdoors here in Colorado.

I thought my reply was in emu-land, but I can see it if I click on the timestamp of your comment. 

That‚Äôs no way to encourage a dialogue, which is the main attraction of this forum for me.
Right when I thought these were getting too easy, this one stumped me, specifically the top left‚Ä¶ finally relented and had to look up the 1956 presidential race to get things going. A toughie!
Shouldn‚Äôt ‚Äúunion‚Äù in 45A be capitalized?
I honestly thought the ‚Äúzoomies‚Äù was a word my wife made up to perfectly describe our mini dachshund after every bath.

On a cruise in the Bering Sea but stopped in to do this puzzle.  Took me extra long but got it with no real lookups, just a few confirmations, like the spelling of shakshuka which I'd never heard of.  I did confirm Adlai was the opponent of Ike in 1956, and I made sure reiki was what I thought.  I would have gotten factorial more easily if I could have seen it was ! and not a I.  Last square was the cross of CSI and ASL, which I got just by trying different letters.  Clues made sense once I got it.

I'll try again because it looks like the censors grabbed my post again.  SIGH......  


Things that made that made me smile as I solved today. 

[Bass output] for ALES. Great clue. 

SHAKSHUKA, one of my favorite pantry dinners. 

TAKI because I remembered it from Connections earlier in the week. 

ZOOMIES, because how can that not make you smile? 

ARTISANAL crossing A_A_. Especially after talking to an ARTISANAL CHEESE maker at a farmers market recently. Yup, definitely _N_L. And that's a good thing.  
(Is that what the censors didn't like today?)

Manchego CHEESE. So good. 

Now, if I can refrain from reading the news for another hour or so, I can PROLONG this feeling.

Another annoying thing about the comment software.

I used to be able to just toggle between "Reader picks" and "All" to refresh the comments.  Now, on my tablet using Firefox browser, I have to close out the column, reopen it, and then view the comments.  This has been going on for a week or so.  

Just me?

I did report it, but I haven't heard back yet.

Half average solve time, but Connections was a complete train wreck, and still haven't gotten the pangram in Spelling Bee.

Someone needs to get a life.

Oh, man, this puzzle was so fresh!  Many puzzles have a been-there feel ‚Äì dominated by seen-before words and clues.  There‚Äôs a charm in running across old friends, yes, but there‚Äôs excitement in meeting new ones.

My brain exults at cracking new riddles, and my brain‚Äôs tail never stopped wagging today.

Freshness?  How about 11 NYT answer debuts, six once-befores, and four twice-befores (Hi, @Rich!)?  That‚Äôs nearly a third of the answers bringing the sheen of newness to the box, making for a perfect echo of spring.  

Mind you, being a debut answer doesn‚Äôt guarantee that it‚Äôs good.  But these are.  Look at them! ‚Äì AGED CHEESE / ARTISANAL / DONE TO A TEE / FACTORIAL / HAD NO CHILL / LETS FACE IT / LOSER PAYS / PREHAB / SHAKSHUKA / ZIP ME UP / ZOOMIES.  Wow!

So here I am, reveling through the new, when along comes an LOL moment: Seeing [Common tater].  Hah!  Big hah!

Happy moment on top of happy brain, and Crosslandia comes through again.  Sterling, sterling experience, your puzzle, Michael.  What a boost ‚Äì thank you!
The northwest corner here was unbearable ‚Äî way too much obscure stuff.

For me, this was more like a general knowledge quiz where I'm not familiar with the some of the clues or answers. I know - American newspaper!
The slang "Let's be real", TAKI, the initialisms (ASL? SSR? ATF?) and then PREHAB! 
Help please with SPIEL and the clue.

TAKI is taki-ing over the world!

Showed up here a few weeks ago, 
hubby was surprised I‚Äôd never heard of them.

Within 2 days, family I shop for had
some odd spelling on the Trader Joe‚Äôs list.

Then a comedian talking TAKI.

Then an ad.

I‚Äôve now been exposed to TAKI in about 15 
different places and forms.

And, um‚Ä¶they‚Äôre *not* good!

But I‚Äôm keeping a pocketful of TAKI 
from now on. 
It ain‚Äôt going away soon!

Happy Saturday all!

Enjoyable but a toughie. So many phrases/candidates/ science-ey based stuff I didn‚Äôt know, it felt like a proper workout.  

I thought I was off to a flying start with 1A and 23A total gimmes, then the wheels fell off. Not complaining though; my brain thanks you for the workout. Haven‚Äôt got any energy left for ZOOMIES, so a gentle stroll with the HOUND through the orchards will do. The blossom is out, the heat has abated to a more seasonal 20c. Lovely.

Chiming in on the chat box here‚Ä¶

My comments are just as they‚Äôve always been.
Only difference is that they are held back for hours,
or they disappear.

Not shorter, 
not controversial (unless hot chips are a hot topic),
just‚Ä¶*poof*!

Glitch..?

Another good puzzle. All of the math/science clues slow me down. I have to rely on the crosses or look things up. Still, I love learning things from the puzzle. Thanks!

As a Canadian, that upper-left corner was BRUTAL. An obscure American politician, an abbreviated US federal government organization, a British brewing company, a Hawaiian word‚Ä¶ The cross of 1D and 22A was also very difficult without knowing that obscure politician, since there are many countries with more than 50% desert and guessing without the first letter is pointless. When I had ‚ÄúCEI‚Äù in a row from FACTORIAL, ATEAM, and REIKI (all straightforward clues) I assumed the end of ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs be real‚Ä¶‚Äù involved DECEIT, not FACE IT. Not an easy solve for me at all.

There were several words and phrases in this puzzle that I was unfamiliar, but they didn't slow me down.  SPITS GAME is an especially fun phrase to learn.  (However, I don't think I'll be adding it to my conversations anytime soon.)

But by far my favorite was the term PREHAB for "physical therapy before an operation".  Even though I'd never heard of it before, it's the kind of word that, when you see it, you think, "There's a word that ought to exist."

Didn't know SPITSGAME, REIKI, SHAKSHUKA or HADNOCHILL, but, LETSFACEIT, THATSONME. 

Nonetheless, solved this puzzle unaided---but only because I (think I) recalled TAKI from earlier this year.

This one seemed like an appropriately challenging puzzle for a Saturday. It also seemed quite fair, given that I was able to use crosses to cover for my ignorance of some of the fill.

Never had an ELKHOUND, but when my beagle mix got the ZOOMIES, he was certainly thinking "[Get out of my way!]"

Nice puzzle, with more than a few tricky bits. Like:

A person who tries without much success to smooth talk: spits lame. 
Which makes the answer to intervals : LAPS

Finally changing SnIT to SKIT got me to the music

Is it cheating when you have the whole puzzle done except for one square and you put every letter in the alphabet in, one at a time, until you finally get the music? Because that's how this puzzle ended for me

A suitable Saturday challenge‚Ä¶quite a few I had to really work to solve. Funny thing‚Ä¶I had to laugh when I saw 23A, ZOOMIES, which was a word I‚Äôd never heard until a couple months ago when the trainer we took our dog to a couple months after we‚Äôd rescued him used it to describe a behavior. Our previous dogs were more placid.

What made me laugh was that, just as I was sitting at the table with the CW and my coffee, my wife came downstairs with Monty and he dashed into the kitchen, skittering as he took the corner from the dining room. Then, there‚Äôs 23A, as if the constructor was right there, thinking, ‚ÄúOoh, that‚Äôs a good one!‚Äù

It's been too long since I read ANIMAL FARM, apparently, but eventually I worked it out, and it gave me 7D (when was that adopted??)  
Really great puzzle, though I saw the byline and moaned, because we need to get out the door and on the  road.  Happily surprised to get the grid filled in jig time.  
Manchego is our new fave ingredient!  Those who are lactose-intolerant will be pleased!  
Doubt I will meet SHAKSHUKA along the culinary road of life, but I do hate missing out on yummy food.  
Good solving, friends!
As much as I'd like to collaborate with Michael Lieberman, not only am I not in the same league, but my abysmal lack of constructing talent is, so far, legendary. Maybe some day...

Fun puzzle. Finished in half my average time, but still found some challenges.

Until earlier this week I had never heard of TAKIs, then they appeared in Connections (or was it Strands?). Still, I can't be the only reader here who instinctively thinks only of TAKI183 when I see that. All those hours on the subway on my way to high school, and that really sticks with me.

Thanks!

I always assumed TAKI was short for taquito, since they're both rolled-up tortillas. But yes, the flavors are terrifying. I feel like there are only two types of people: people who like TAKIs, and people who respect their 56A health. I will eat a bag occasionally, but it will hurt me.
Thanks for the shout out to Taki T. I really miss his amusing column in The Spectator!

I got this one in 26 mins! My best saturday time yet. I was pretty proud of Shakshuka, I've cooked it many times since I once ordered it off a menu blindly.

I had PREGAS for 43 down for a good while lol

"Zip me up, Scotty."

"She cannae take any more, Captain! She's gonna Blow!"





("I never said most of the things I said." - Yogi Berra)
Day 364.  This was a slog for me.  Snit instead of skit made SHANSH_KA a significant challenge.  Whew.

Perhaps I am just small of brain this morning but this was a proper workout with special mention to the SW and SPITSGAME.  But I pulled it off eventually.  Many thanks. 

I see the comments below (Barry, Nancy J and Eric) about clicking on the timestamp to enable seeing all the comments in a thread?  First I've heard about this one.  I have noticed weird behavior here lately (and I don't mean the commenters).

Fifteen seconds off my best Saturday time, and that was after getting about five across answers on first pass. So many fun ones: ALES, ZOOMIES, ELKHOUND, and PREHAB were favorites for this Bass-drinking, dog-adoring physical therapist, but how could you not also love SPITSGAME, HADNOCHILL, and AGEDCHEESE? The German spelling for "Lowenbrau product" and the clue for GLUON were also just lovely.  

I just wish it didn't go by for me as quickly as it did! A happy May weekend to my puzzling fellows!

Oof five minutes above average and had to start googling to check my spellings and entries after I had it filled it. The error I couldn‚Äôt see was I had SNIT for ‚Äúsmall drama‚Äù, and though I‚Äôve eaten shakshouka, the word didn‚Äôt come to mind and it appears to have several spellings in the Latin script‚Ä¶. I think I‚Äôm trying to justify my googling to myself. I‚Äôm fine with it. Thanks for letting me talk that out fellow puzzlers.
Not sure a country that's committing genocide and recently bombed an aid boat should be a crossword clue, Michael.
Fast and fresh

Can we please have a second set of puzzles Thursday through Saturday? I know my brain isn‚Äôt getting better, but yesterday and today I finished the puzzles almost 15 minutes faster than average. When I do archive Thursday-Saturday (from the 90‚Äôs and early aughts), my times are much longer. It‚Äôs no fun finishing a Saturday in 7.5 minutes. The puzzles are getting easier. I‚Äôm sure there are many others who want tougher solves.

So many vocalizations.  I hate those as much as most commenters seem to hate rebuses.  It's like we're relying on needing to be psychic to make the puzzles difficult instead of wordplay and misdirection. Leaves me wanting a challenge.  Time to go back to the archives.
Wow, this was very challenging and rewarding. Got a little tripped up with my lack of knowledge in North African cuisine. Well constructed!

I see our favorite EGG-HEADED politician and "two-time loser to DDE" is back for more abuse. My favorite ADLAI Stevenson quote: "Newspaper editors separate the wheat from the chaff, and then they print the chaff." I might not have gotten that answer without knowing Estes Kefauver was his running mate. Wow, that's a tough clue! But hey, if we're making Saturday hard again, count me in. SHAKSHUKA? I had SnIT crossing, as did many, I see.

Fun Fact: Bass ALE'S distinctive red triangle was the first registered trademark in the UK. Legend has it that the brewery dispatched an employee to wait at the patent office overnight, so that they could be first in line.
This puzz was too hard
Country that is more than 50% stolen land: Abbr.

Pretty smooth solve, quite a bit faster than my rolling average, but lasted as long as my coffee, which--let's face it--is the important thing.

Forgot before filling in the last letter that I had meant to go back and check the African dish because I knew my spelling was not quite right. So that held up the happy music for a few moments. 

I did enjoy the NW, at first not knowing how to get a purchase, then staring and seeing some things to try, and watching it fall into place.

The colloquial and modern slang was so charming. If I knew it, I didn't know I knew it, but now I do and will probably use it.

Yay!

GLUON and FACTORIAL -- be still my geeky heart.

And SNIT vs SKIT taught me a new word. I need to find a good recipe and try it out. 

Thanks for the fun Saturday challenge! Timing-wise, it wasn't too bad, but I had to think!

That was a rough one for me. Sat with SHANSHUKA and SNIT until I finally looked up the dish since the puzzle wasn't as convinced regarding its completion as I was. ADLAI and Estes was also not in the same zip code as my wheelhouse. I really liked the nexus of ZOOMIES, BIER, and ZIPMEUP; that was amazingly tight.

I sympathize with people who want a hard enough solve but this one was hard enough for me and really fun!  After 45‚Äô+ I went to Caitlin‚Äôs column and just having TAKI correct sewed it up for me. 

If I wanted real speed I‚Äôd do this on a laptop but I don‚Äôt want to get myself into video-game type anxiety for an activity that I like to enjoy. 

Some this week were easy and I solved below average but today‚Äôs I thought was perfect. I do
remember when I used to take an hour for Saturday in 2020. No lookups on this but was tempted to word-check. Didn‚Äôt:)
 
ps: I knew SHAKSHUKA but wasn‚Äôt sure of GLUON.
At first was stumped by the clue for FACTORIAL 
but then it came to me as that was one of my favorite chapters in Trigonometry(?) Thanks!

A record for me - I didn't get anything for Connections - and when all was revealed, I wasn't much wiser. I usually get one or two lines right. Always a word or an expression that I don't know in the American context. Yesterday - dog was meant to be hot dog!
The corner I was stuck on was the corner with the slang I've never heard--"spit game." Is it a phrase Michael Lieberman uses?
I did fairly well, but being unfamiliar with SHAKSHUKA, I had SNIT for "small drama" forever until SKIT occurred to me.

I made solid progress on this puzzle until the NW corner - nothing there stacked easily for me, and TAKI was the only thing I was sure of. CHARLOTTES WEB didn‚Äôt fit at 1-Across, maybe SAINT FRANCIS?

FBI or ATF? HOARS or NOELS? MESS, MUSS, FUSS? ATTIC or ATEAM? METIER and REIKI are not in my wheelhouse so nothing helped there.

Finally I had a peek at the blog and found ANIMAL FARM, (of course), then the rest started to fall into place.

GUNS before PUNS also slowed me down for a spell.

Cheers
Finally, a challenge.

This was a very satisfying Saturday for me. I'm pet-free, so ZOOMIES was unknown to me - and so were SPITS GAME, LOA, SHAKSHUKA, REIKI, TAKI, ELKSHOUNDS, and the delightful HAD NO CHILL. Yet, no lookups for me today, which I attribute to adroit clueing of crosses and simple dumb luck. I gasped, truly surprised, when changing SNIT to SKIT gave me the happy music. Thanks for the fun!

2 comments per hour seems like a very slow day for the comments section.

I think I have 2 comments confiscated and being body-searched.

This comment is just a test comment.

I wish constructors/editors would avoid references to ‚ÄúIsrael‚Äù.  I do puzzles to take my mind off of the world‚Äôs problems; I don‚Äôt like to be reminded of the genocide we‚Äôre aiding & abetting.
Fun puzzle, the ADLER/ADLAI bookends were a nice touch and gave me some trouble, not knowing either. But finally managed based on crosses.
Kind of a weird one for me, but 11D gave me so much joy as a longtime fan of The Bugle. Andy will be so happy.
If you thought this was a challenging Saturday, try Saturday, July 20, 2002 by Dana Motley. Whooo-eee!
I never meet a pun I didn't like.
I thought maybe SPITS GAME was SPITS LAME because the clue made it seem like an unsuccessful attempt, and I had GAPS as LAPS, thinking they were intervals of a race track.

Three clues labeled as colloquial or slang with answers I've never encountered anywhere.

An average number.

Most people live in apartments rather than houses over here. Barbecuing on balconies is illegal, and on the lawns between apartment buildings it is frowned upon. However, every Polish city and town has a communal barbecuing area, sometimes officially designated by the municipal authorities and the fire department.

Under "communism," the authorities wanted people to do everything together rather than individually - this also applied to recreation, rest and relaxation. Communal recreational areas were created, with sport, cultural and leisure facilities, often in forests, on lakeshores or riverbanks. It was one of the pretty cool features of that regime.

These places survive, like the Park Kultury (Culture Park) in Powsin, on the edge of the Kabacki Forest, just south of where I live. I used to go there as a kid with my parents, and it is one of my favorite destinations for long walks even at present.

Well, anyway, democracy and market economy brought with them barbecuing culture (unknown in Poland pre-1989: back then we baked sausages over bonfires and baked potatoes in their smoldering ashes; nobody owned a grill, and we did not know hamburgers). Those "communist" recreational areas have become top barbecuing spots, with hundreds of people grilling away on weekends, and the Long Weekend, too. 

Ukrainians have had a similar communal culture for decades, so they gladly come to places like Powsin, too. Ukrainian of refugees and expats is almost as common as Polish there now.

@Beth Thank you! For some historic pictures of the Powsin recreational area: https://haloursynow.pl/pl/15_fotorelacje/379_inne/3854_tak-wypoczywali-nasi-dziadkowie-w-powsinie-unikalne-zdjecia-foto.html The decades of "communism" weren't all doom and gloom.

The SAT (once short for Scholastic Aptitude Test, then changed to Scholastic Achievement Test when people claimed it didn't measure aptitude very well), and now is just alphabet soup, is an exam taken in the 11th or 12th grade that may have a major bearing on college admissions decisions.

The PSAT (P for preliminary) is a practice version of the SAT given in 10th or early 11th grade; in addition to being a practice for the SAT, it is also a qualifying exam for national merit scholarships.

The LSAT is the Law School Admissions test, and is not related to the other two.

"ASL" is American Sign Language, used by the deaf community in Canada and the United States.
